The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values determined for sodium styrenesulfonate in aqueous solution are 2.0 and −0.4, respectively. The values previously published for potassium styrenesulfonate in dimethylformamide solution, 9.18 and 1.32, respectively, indicate that the styrenesulfonic acid is a highly reactive monomer containing a vinyl group with a polarity strongly positive with respect to styrene. However, the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values presented here denote a reactive monomer with the vinyl group polarized only slightly more positive than styrene. The consequences of these differences are shown in the prediction of copolymer compositions.</jats:p>

Title: Composition Regulation by Flow Copolymerization of Methyl Methacrylate and Glycidyl Methacrylate with Free Radical Method
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>It is important to match the feeding ratio of comonomers to the composition ratio in the resulting copolymers as closely as possible in industrial production, where the goal is often to produce more a homogeneous composition in copolymers. In this study, a flow copolymerization system with a conventionally initiated free radical method, together with randomly selected polymerization conditions is investigated. It is succeeded in achieving a closer match between the composition ratio and feeding ratio than previously reported in the copolymerization of styrene with methyl methacrylate and of glycidyl methacrylate with methyl methacrylate, which will widen the range of applications, by precisely controlling the mixing and heating in a flow polymerization apparatus. This is confirmed by the fact that the estimated values of reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, which are used in the reaction kinetics of copolymerization, are close to 1.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Acrylonitrile and ω-Substituted 1-Olefins -Increased Reactivity of Olefin Monomers with the Pendant Aromatic Group
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Alternating copolymerization of β‐methylstyrene and maleic anhydride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Alternating copolymers of β‐methylstyrene and maleic anhydride were prepared by free‐radical‐initiated polymerization in bulk and in toluene as a solvent. The reactivity ratios <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>1c</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>2c</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> were calculated from the change of copolymerization rate with a monomer feed at a constant total monomer concentration according to the generalized model of Shirota and coworkers. From the equation <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>) + <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>(CT) were calculated <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>) and <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>(CT), and it was found that in toluene the copolymerization proceeds predominantly by the addition of CT‐complex monomers. Termination occurs predominantly by homotermination of β‐methyl‐styrene macro free radicals, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t22</jats:sub>, but the cross termination <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t21</jats:sub> is also operative.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics studies on copolymerization of acrylonitrile vinyl acids by solvent–water suspension polymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Polyacrylonitrile is an important polymer that is widely used in the manufacture of synthetic fibers, particularly for applications in apparel. Although a vast amount of literature is available on the polymerization process of acrylonitrile (AN) with other monomers, there are few reports of studies on polymerization in a mixed solvent of water with an organic solvent. It is conceivable that this method could combine the advantages of the solution and suspension polymerization methods. Synthesis of AN copolymers with two vinyl acids, methacrylic acid (MAA) and itaconic acid (IA), is carried out by solvent–water suspension polymerization. The polymerizations are performed with an equal ratio mixture of dimethylformamide as a solvent and water as a nonsolvent at 60°C using α,α‐azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator. The kinetics of polymerization are studied by plotting the conversion versus reaction time for different mole ratios of AN with vinyl acids. Copolymers are characterized by FTIR and capillary viscometery. The results show that IA depresses the rate of polymerization more than MAA in this reaction medium, and this effect becomes more significant at higher vinyl acid mole ratios. High conversion in a short reaction time is obtainable for copolymers with a low vinyl acid mole fraction. However, for mole ratios of more than 93:7, the rate of the reaction is drastically reduced and low conversion (<60%) results, even after 8 h. The intrinsic viscosities of all cases are surprisingly high. Although they are reduced with increasing acidic comonomer mole fraction, this reduction is more significant for IA compared to MAA. © 2005 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 97: 1284–1291, 2005</jats:p>

Title: Molecular orbital calculation of monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Kinetics and Modeling of Aqueous Phase Radical Homopolymerization of 3-(Methacryloylaminopropyl)trimethylammonium Chloride and its Copolymerization with Acrylic Acid
Abstract: <jats:p>The radical homopolymerization kinetics of 3-(methacryloylaminopropyl) trimethylammonium chloride (MAPTAC) and its batch copolymerization with nonionized acrylic acid (AA) in aqueous solution are investigated and modeled. The drift in monomer composition is measured during copolymerization by in situ NMR over a range of initial AA molar fractions and monomer weight fractions up to 0.35 at 50 °C. The copolymer becomes enriched in MAPTAC for monomer mixtures containing up to 60 mol% MAPTAC, but is enriched in AA for MAPTAC-rich mixtures; this azeotropic behavior is dependent on initial monomer content, as electrostatic interactions from the cationic charges influence the system reactivity ratios. Models for MAPTAC homopolymerization and AA-MAPTAC copolymerization are developed to represent the rates of monomer conversion and comonomer composition drifts over the complete range of experimental conditions.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of Reactivity Ratios from Binary Copolymerization Using the k-Nearest Neighbor Non-Parametric Regression
Abstract: <jats:p>This paper proposes a new method for calculating the monomer reactivity ratios for binary copolymerization based on the terminal model. The original optimization method involves a numerical integration algorithm and an optimization algorithm based on k-nearest neighbour non-parametric regression. The calculation method has been tested on simulated and experimental data sets, at low (<10%), medium (10–35%) and high conversions (>40%), yielding reactivity ratios in a good agreement with the usual methods such as intersection, Fineman–Ross, reverse Fineman–Ross, Kelen–Tüdös, extended Kelen–Tüdös and the error in variable method. The experimental data sets used in this comparative analysis are copolymerization of 2-(N-phthalimido) ethyl acrylate with 1-vinyl-2-pyrolidone for low conversion, copolymerization of isoprene with glycidyl methacrylate for medium conversion and copolymerization of N-isopropylacrylamide with N,N-dimethylacrylamide for high conversion. Also, the possibility to estimate experimental errors from a single experimental data set formed by n experimental data is shown.</jats:p>

Title: Microemulsion copolymerization of styrene and acrylonitrile with n‐butanol as the cosurfactant
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The microemulsion copolymerization of styrene and acrylonitrile in an <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butanol/cetyltrimethylammonium bromide/oil/water microemulsion system was studied. The solubilization sites of the two monomers were determined with an NMR technique. The results showed that the solubilization behaviors of the two monomers were quite different. Most of the styrene was solubilized in the palisade layer of the microemulsion, whereas the acrylonitrile had an equilibrium distribution in the aqueous phase and palisade layer of the microemulsion. The reactivity ratios of styrene and acrylonitrile in the microemulsion system were different from those in other media. The effect of the monomer feed composition on the copolymerization kinetics was investigated, and the mechanism of nucleation of the latex particles was examined. The experimental results showed that the copolymerization loci were changed from the microemulsion droplets to the aqueous phase when the concentration of acrylonitrile in the monomer feed reached approximately 80%; this could be further proved by the effect of the monomer feed composition on the copolymerization kinetics. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 43: 203–216, 2005</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis, microstructure, and copolymerization studies of 2‐chloroethyl α‐chloroacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Poly(2‐chloroethyl α‐chloroacrylate) was synthesized by radical initiation, and its microstructure was evaluated using carbon‐13 NMR. Methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and 2‐chloroethyl α‐chloroacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were copolymerized in toluene at 55°C using azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The reactivity ratios are 0.37 ± 0.28 and 1.21 ± 2.26, The thermal properties of these copolymers have also been reported.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization with Ziegler-Natta catalysts—II. Monomer reactivity ratios for several olefin pairs
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Controlled radical copolymerization of β‐pinene and acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The feasibility of the radical copolymerization of β‐pinene and acrylonitrile was clarified for the first time. The monomer reactivity ratios evaluated by the Fineman–Ross method were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>β‐pinene</jats:sub> = 0 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>acrylonitrile</jats:sub> = 0.66 in dichloroethane at 60 °C with AIBN, which indicated that the copolymerization was a simple alternating copolymerization. The addition of the Lewis acid Et<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>AlCl increased the copolymerization rate and enhanced the incorporation of β‐pinene. The first example for the synthesis of an almost perfectly alternating copolymer of β‐pinene and acrylonitrile was achieved in the presence of Et<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>AlCl. Furthermore, the possible controlled copolymerization of β‐pinene and acrylonitrile was then attempted via the reversible addition–fragmentation transfer (RAFT) technique. At a low β‐pinene/acrylonitrile feed ratio of 10/90 or 25/75, the copolymerization with 2‐cyanopropyl‐2‐yl dithiobenzoate as the transfer agent displayed the typical features of living polymerization. However, the living character could be observed only within certain monomer conversions. At higher monomer conversions, the copolymerizations deviated from the living behavior, probably because of the competitive degradative chain transfer of β‐pinene. The β‐pinene/acrylonitrile copolymers with a high alternation degree and controlled molecular weight were also obtained by the combination of the RAFT agent cumyl dithiobenzoate and Lewis acid Et<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>AlCl. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 44: 2376–2387, 2006</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of methacrylaldehyde with hydrophilic monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of methacrylaldehyde with hydrophilic monomers — 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate, 5‐hydroxy‐3‐oxapentyl methacrylate, 8‐hydroxy‐3,6‐dioxaoctyl methacrylate, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ethylmethacrylamide, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐diethylacrylamide, and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐diethylmethacrylamide — were prepared by solution polymerization in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide initiated with 2,2′‐azodiisobutyronitrile. In the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde (1) with 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (2) (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,77, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,36) and in the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐diethylacrylamide (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3,79, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,14) the content of CHO groups corresponds to that ot methacrylaldehyde units in the triads comonomer — methacrylaldehyde — comonomer; in the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ethylmethacrylamide (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4,07, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,14) both comonomers react with each other and the content of CHO groups is very low, while in the copolymer of methacrylaldehyde with 5‐hydroxy‐3‐oxapentyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,48, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,34) the majority of methacrylaldehyde units contain an unreacted CHO group.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of isopropenyl and isopropylidene oxazolones with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Isopropenyl‐4‐isopropyl‐2‐oxazolin‐5‐one (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), was copolymerized with styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), and the monomer reactivity ratios were determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.31 ± 0.03, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.12 ± 0.10. New isomerized oxazolones (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), 2‐isopropylidene‐4‐methyl‐3‐oxazolin‐5‐one, 2‐isopropylidene‐4‐isopropyl‐3‐oxazolin‐5‐one, and 2‐isopropylidene‐4‐isobutyl‐3‐oxazolin‐5‐one were prepared and copolymerized with styrene. The monomer reactivity ratios were: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.36 = 0.07, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.0; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.39 ± 0.06, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.00 ± 0.10; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.39 ± 0.10, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.0, respectively. The isomerized oxazolones showed no tendency towards homopolymerization by radical initiator. From the results of infrared and NMR spectra and hydrolysis of the copolymer, it was indicated that the isomerized oxazolones participated in copolymerization in the form of 1–4 polymerization of the conjugated dienes (exo double bond at C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and the CN in the ring). Copolymers reacted with nucleophilic reagents such as amines and alcohols.</jats:p>

Title: Controlled/living copolymerization of styrene and acrylamide in DMF with Fe/TMEDA complex as catalyst
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In this work, Fe(0)‐mediated single electron‐living radical copolymerization of styrene (St) and acrylamide (AM) was investigated at ambient temperature in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide using carbon tetrachloride as initiator and tetramethylethylenediamine as ligand. Kinetic studies showed that the copolymerization followed the first‐order kinetics model. The resulting copolymers of St and AM possessed predetermined molecular weights and narrow molecular weight distribution, which agreed with the character of controlled/living polymerization. On the basis of Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), proton nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), the monomer reactivity ratios were calculated. The amount of ligand played an important role in copolymerization. The obtained polymer was characterized by FTIR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR, <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR, and gel permeation chromatography. The living characteristics were demonstrated by chain extension experiment. © 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem. 2013, 51, 2919–2924</jats:p>

Title: New simple procedures for the prediction of monomer reactivity ratios and transfer constants in radical polymerisation
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> and Patterns of Reactivity schemes for the quantitative treatment of the reactions of polymer radicals both suffer from drawbacks which seriously limit their usefulness. Two revised versions of the Patterns of Reactivity scheme, in which all the necessary parameters are derived from experimental data, are summarised here. Both new schemes provide significantly more accurate assessments of monomer reactivity ratios and transfer constants than do their predecessors.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic study of methacrylate copolymerization systems by thermoanalysis methods
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical solution copolymerization of isobutyl methacrylate with lauryl methacrylate in the presence of an inhibitor was studied with thermoanalysis methods. A set of inhibited polymerization experiments was designed. Four different levels of initial inhibitor/initiator molar ratios were considered. <jats:italic>In situ</jats:italic> polymerization experiments were carried out with differential scanning calorimetry. Furthermore, to determine the impact of the polymerization media on the rate of initiation, the kinetics of the initiator decomposition were followed with nonisothermal thermoanalysis methods, and the results were compared with <jats:italic>in situ</jats:italic> polymerization counterparts. The robust <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>‐estimation method was used to retrieve the kinetic parameters of the copolymerization system. This estimation method led to a reasonable prediction error for the dataset with strong multicollinearity. The model‐free isoconversional method was employed to find the variation of the Arrhenius activation energy with the conversion. It was found that robust <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>‐estimation outperformed existing methods of estimation in terms of statistical precision and computational speed, while maintaining good robustness. © 2008 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 2008</jats:p>

Title: A kinetic investigation of styrene/butyl acrylate copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>An experimental investigation of the kinetics of the bulk free radical copolymerization of styrene/butyl acrylate initiated with 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was conducted at 50°C using various initiator concentrations and initial monomer ratios including the azeotropic composition.</jats:p><jats:p>Reactivity ratios were determined by analyzing composition data using the error‐in‐variables model. The experiments, designed using the Tidwell‐Mortimer criterion, were conducted in sealed ampoules at 50°C to low conversion levels (< 7%).</jats:p><jats:p>From the calculated reactivity ratios, the azeotropic composition was determined and further experiments were run at these conditions as well as at two other initial monomer feed compositions in order to collect composition, rate and molecular weight data. The experiments were run through the full conversion range at two different initiator concentrations.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios of vinyl chloride‐vinyl acetate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of itaconic anhydride and styrene, determination of reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of itaconic anhydride and styrene has been studied and the<jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>‐r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic>values determined. In benzene<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>= 0.78,<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>= 0.015; in tetrahydrofuran<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>0.60, =<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.10. One possible explanation of the definite positive deviation from constant values in the different solvents has been advanced; it is based on the fact that the copolymer precipitates from benzene as formed. In all cases the<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>,<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>product is in the order of 0.01 to 0.06 and indicates that the copolymer is highly alternating in structure. Excellent agreement has been obtained between values of copolymer compositions by analysis and values predicted by copolymer theory based on the copolymer equation. Copolymers of molecular weights in the order of 50,000 to 150,000 (determined by light scattering) were prepared. The rate of copolymerization was about twenty times faster in benzene than in tetrahydrofuran.</jats:p>

Title: Terminal and Penultimate Reactivity Ratios in the Styrene-Acrylonitrile Free-Radical Copolymerization System in Bulk
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with Acrolein and Crotonaldehyde
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Graft copolymerization of acrylonitrile, methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate on bleached holocellulose by use of ceric ions
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Graft copolymers of acrylonitrile, methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate on bleached holocellulose were obtained by the use of ceric ions. The ceric ion concentration, at which maximum graft levels were attained, depends on the type of monomer. The dependence of the extent of graft copolymer formation on the monomer type is explained in terms of the difference in the effective concentration of the monomers at the cellulose‐water interface.</jats:p>

Title: Batch emulsion copolymerization of butyl acrylate and methyl methacrylate in the presence of sodium dodecyl sulfate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Kinetics of batch emulsion copolymerization of butyl acrylate (BuA) with methyl methacrylate (MMA) have been investigated using sodium dodecyl sulfate as emulsifier and the redox system potassium peroxodisulfate (K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>S<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>)/sodium disulfite (Na<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>S<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>) as initiator. Latexes have been characterized with regard to their copolymer composition through <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR analysis and particle size distribution by a quasi‐elastic light scattering (QELS) technique or transmission electron microscopy. The effect of the monomer feed composition on the average copolymer composition vs. conversion was first studied in order to derive emulsion reactivity ratios. However, simulation of experimental data based on monomer partitioning (due to the high water solubility of MMA) and particle swelling was better accounted for when considering bulk reactivity ratios together with polymerization in the aqueous phase (in addition to that in the main locus of the polymer particles). Then, the influence of several pertinent parameters, such as emulsifier concentration, amount of initiator, monomer‐to‐water ratio and addition of an organic solvent has been examined in relation to the actual polymerization mechanism.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated copolymers of styrene and p‐formylstyrene, 1. Solution copolymerization and characterization
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Kinetics of solution homopolymerization of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐formylstyrene<jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#note1" /><jats:fn><jats:p>System name: 4‐vinylbenzaldehyde.</jats:p></jats:fn>
 (A) and copolymerization with styrene (S) have been examined at 60°C in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide with 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile as initiator. For <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐formylstyrene, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0025116X:media:MACP021930118:tex2gif-stack-1" /> = 0,135 L<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> · mol<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup> was estimated from the plot of monomer consumption versus time, i.e. a value greater than that for styrene (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> are the rate constants of propagation and termination and termination, respectively). Reactivity ratios have been determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 3,0 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>S</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 0.2, indicating the reactivity of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐formylstyrene to be higher than that of styrene. Moreover, from initial copolymerization rates, the cross termination factor was calculated and found to depend upon the copolymer composition. Some solution properties of the homo‐ and copolymers have been analysed: solubility of (co)polymers, their molecular weight and its distribution (by gel permeation chromatography), and their composition and monomer sequence distribution (using <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectroscopy).</jats:p>

Title: Radical terpolymerization of vinyl sulfide, vinyl ether, and maleic anhydride. Evaluation of the reactivities of vinyl sulfide and vinyl ether alternative copolymerization. IV
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The terpolymerizations of maleic anhydride (MAn), vinyl sulfide (VS) and vinyl ether (VE) initiated by α.α′‐azobisisobutyronitrile were investigated in order to evaluate the reactivities of VS and VE toward poly(MAn) radical. Since both VS and VE undergo alternative copolymerization with MAn, these terpolymerizations were approximately treated on the basis of the free propagation and complex propagation mechanisms. From the treatment of the free propagation mechanism in which only three free monomers can participate, the reactivity of the free VS toward attack of the poly(MAn) radical was found to be 4.24 to 6.63 times higher than that of free VE, and the difference in activation energy was 1.5 kcal/mole. The higher reactivity of VS than VE might be explained by the 3 d orbital resonance between the propagating radical and the adjacent sulfur atom in VS. According to the complex propagation mechanism in which only two complexed monomers can participate, the reactivity ratios of the MAn/VS and MAn/VE complex monomers were also determined. It was found that the former complex was more reactive than the latter complex toward the poly(MAn) radical.</jats:p>

Title: Polymerization and Copolymerization of p-Vinylbenzylmethylcarbinol
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: The polymerization and copolymerization of alkylvinylacetylene derivatives
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>With the use of free radical initiators, homopolymers from vinylacetylene (I), 2‐ethyl‐1‐vinylacetylene (II), isopropenylacetylene (III), and 2‐ethyl‐1‐isopropenylacetylene (IV) have been prepared in which the ethynyl group was largely preserved. Copolymers of these monomers with methyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, acrylonitrile, styrene, and 2‐vinylpyridine have also been prepared. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were determined from 2‐vinylpyridine and acrylonitrile copolymers: <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.50, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.40 for vinylacetylene; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.44, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.35 for 2‐ethyl‐1‐vinylacetylene; and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.35, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.30 for isopropenylacetylene. The polymers absorbed oxygen and became crosslinked and insoluble on exposure to air, which complicated, the investigation of molecular weight and ultraviolet spectra.</jats:p>

Title: Semi‐continuous emulsion copolymerization of vinyl acetate and butyl acrylate using a new protective colloid. Part 2. Effects of monomer ratio and initiator
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Poly(vinyl acetate‐co‐butyl acrylate) latexes with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylol acrylamide were prepared by semi‐continuous emulsion polymerization. The influence of the different initiators and various monomer ratios was studied to relate its physicochemical and colloidal properties. The changes in the copolymer latexes with the use of ammonium persulfate and potassium persulfate initiators were investigated by monitoring viscosity, molecular weights, molecular weight distribution and particle size. It was found that almost all physicochemical and colloidal properties of the latexes followed the same trends for both initiators. Potassium persulfate gave slightly higher results for number‐ and weight‐average molecular weights than ammonium persulfate. Copyright © 2006 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.</jats:p>

Title: Batch emulsion copolymerization of 50/50 vinyl acetate/ n‐butyl acrylate using poly(vinyl alcohol) emulsifier
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the batch emulsion copolymerization of 50/50 vinyl acetate/n‐butyl acrylate mixture, no emulsifier or sodium lauryl sulfate emulsifier gave a n‐butyl acrylate‐rich copolymer until the n‐butyl acrylate became depleted, and a vinyl acetate‐rich copolymer and poly(vinyl acetate) thereafter, as expected from the disparate copolymerization reactivity ratios (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> 0.05; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> 5). In contrast, poly(vinyl alcohol) emulsifier gave an initial polymerization of vinyl acetate at a rate equal to or greater than that of the n‐butyl acrylate up to 7–37% conversion; then, the n‐butyl acrylate polymerized preferentially until it became depleted, followed by the remaining vinyl acetate, to give a vinyl acetate‐rich copolymer and poly(vinyl acetate), as expected from the copolymerization reactivity ratios. The mechanism proposed for this process comprised the grafting of vinyl acetate on the poly(vinyl alcohol) in solution to give a water‐insoluble graft copolymer, which precipitated and served as the <jats:italic>locus</jats:italic> for nucleation of poly(n‐butyl acrylate)‐rich particles. Fully hydrolyzed poly(vinyl alcohol) required a higher degree of grafting to give a water‐insoluble graft copolymer than partially hydrolyzed poly(vinyl alcohol).</jats:p>

Title: Studies on diacetylenic vinyl compounds. II. Copolymerization of phenyl‐4′‐vinylphenylbutadiyne with styrene and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerizations of phenyl‐4′‐vinylphenylbutadiyne (PVPB) with styrene and methyl methacrylate were carried out under various conditions. PVPB was more readily incorporated in copolymerization than the comonomers, but the diacetylenic group of PVPB interacted with the propagating radical, decreasing the polymerization rate and the molecular weight of copolymer. When the polymerization system became very viscous, crosslinking took place giving light green luminescent gels. The thermal behaviors of copolymers were also studied.</jats:p>

Title: Investigation of the copolymerization of mono‐ and bifunctional monomers of methacrylic esters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The relationships of free‐radical copolymerization of mono‐ and bifunctional monomers were investigated taking as an example a model system of monomers: methyl methacrylate (MMA) and 9,10‐dianthrylenedimethyl dimethacrylate (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>). The copolymerization was carried out in toluene at 60°C at a 525: 1 mole ratio of MMA to <jats:bold>1</jats:bold>, with AIBN as initiator. Chemical and luminescent methods for the quantitative determination of bridge bonds containing anthracene moieties in the polymer system and the method of their selective cleavage were developed. Experimental dependences of the concentration of monomers and single and double bonded monomeric units of <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> in the copolymers on the copolymerization time were established. It was found that during the copolymerization the activity of each monomer double bond and that of the pendent double bonds in the monomeric units of <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> in the copolymer are similar. It was shown that over a specific range of changes in the content of bridge bonds (the position of which depends on the length of the chains being crosslinked) the values of the intrinsic viscosity of the copolymer solutions increase cooperatively and gel fraction is formed subsequently.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of ethylene and vinyl acetate at low pressure: Determination of the kinetics by sequential sampling
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In behalf of a detailed study on the course of copolymerization reactions, this paper describes an improved and generally applicable experimental method and an efficient computational procedure to match. The experimental method is based on quantitative gas chromatography, and permits frequent measurement of the monomer feed composition throughout (co)polymerization processes at pressures up to 40 kgf/cm<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> ( = 38.7 atm). The given method is applied to the study of the radical copolymerization of ethylene with vinyl acetate in a series of kinetic experiments, at 62°C and 35 kgf/cm<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> ( = 33.9 atm) in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol, in which 20–40% conversion is reached. Monomer feed composition and degree of conversion are entered into a computational procedure based on nonlinear least‐squares methods applied to the integrated version of the copolymer equation. The experimental data, covering a region of ethylene molar feed fractions between 0.24 and 0.74 and copolymer concentrations up to 8 wt‐%, are precisely consistent with the usual model. The respective reactivity ratios are <jats:italic>r̂</jats:italic><jats:sub>e</jats:sub> = 0.743 ± 0.005 and <jats:italic>r̂</jats:italic><jats:sub>v</jats:sub> = 1.515 ± 0.007.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of N‐vinylcaprolactam and glycidyl methacrylate: Reactivity ratio and composition control
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free‐radical copolymerizations of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylcaprolactam (VCL) and glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) were investigated to synthesize temperature‐responsive reactive copolymers with minimized compositional heterogeneity. The average copolymer composition was determined by Fourier transform infrared and nuclear magnetic resonance techniques. The reactivity ratios for VCL and GMA were found to be 0.0365 ± 0.0009 and 6.44 ± 0.36 by the Fineman–Ross method and 0.039 ± 0.006 and 6.75 ± 0.29 by the Kelen–Tudos method, respectively. When prepared by batch polymerization, VCL–GMA copolymers had a highly heterogeneous composition and fractions of different solubilities in water. The use of a gradual feeding technique, which included the sequential addition of more reactive GMA monomer into the reaction, yielded copolymers with much more homogeneous composition. The produced copolymers with 0.9 and 0.11 fractional GMA contents preserved their temperature‐responsive properties and precipitated from aqueous solutions when the temperature exceeded 31 °C. The GMA units in the VCL–GMA copolymers were capable of reacting with amino end‐functionalized poly(ethylene oxide) at room temperature to produce poly(<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylcaprolactam)–poly(ethylene oxide) graft copolymers. © 2005 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 44: 183–191, 2006</jats:p>

Title: Radiation‐induced copolymerization of methyl trifluoroacrylate with propylene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methyl trifluoroacrylate (MTFA) with propylene in bulk was induced by γ irradiation. A wide range of the initial monomer composition gives an equimolar alternating co‐polymer. The reactivity ratios of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (MTFA) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (propylene) were determined to be 0.01 and 0.005, respectively. The polymerization rate at an equimolar monomer composition is proportional to the 1.0 power of the dose rate. The dose rate dependency of higher than 0.5 may be ascribed to unimolecular termination due to a degradative chain transfer of propagating radicals to propylene. The <jats:italic>G</jats:italic> values of the initiating radical formation and the polymerization reaction were calculated to be 1.78 and 1336, respectively. The dependence of the copolymerization rate on the temperature was small, and the activation energy of copolymerization was 1.1 kcal/mole from −6 to 50°C.</jats:p>

Title: Polymerization and copolymerization of methacrylic esters derived from glycidyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methacrylic esters derived from glycidyl methacrylate and nucleophiles with styrene was carried out. The monomer reactivity ratios of these methacrylic esters were varied with the alkoxy groups of the esters and the solvent used.</jats:p>

Title: Dispersion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate and n‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the dispersion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate (BA), the particle size increases with an increasing MMA fraction in the comonomer. The power dependence of the particle size on the initiator concentration also increases with an increasing MMA concentration. Similar to what can be found in the homopolymerizations, two populations can be observed in the molecular weight distributions of the copolymers. Core–shell structured particles with a poly(methyl methacrylate)‐rich core and a poly(<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate)‐rich shell result from the copolymerizations because of the significantly different reactivity ratios. The reaction rates of the dispersion copolymerization are lower than those of the homopolymerization of BA and close to or lower than those of the homopolymerization of MMA, depending on the ratio of the monomers. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 45: 2105–2112, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Radical Copolymerization of p-Substituted Styrenes
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of N‐chlorophenylmaleimides with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>By radical copolymerization, thermostable copolymers of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(2‐chlorophenyl)maleimide (2CPMI), <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(3‐chlorophenyl)maleimide (3CPMI) and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(4‐chlorophenyl)maleimide (4CPMI) with vinyl acetate were prepared. The values of reactivity ratios determined according to the Kelen‐Tüdős method are: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2CPMI</jats:sub> = 0,148 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VA</jats:sub> = 0,049; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>3CPMI</jats:sub> = 0,221 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VA</jats:sub> = 0,032; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>4CPMI</jats:sub> = 0,655 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VA</jats:sub> = 0,0. The position of the Cl atom in the phenyl ring of CPMI influences the copolymerization kinetics. 2CPMI exhibits the strongest tendency for cross propagation, 4CPMI has the highest ability for homopolymerization. Vinyl acetate in all the three systems forms inactive radicals. The thermostability of all three copolymers is higher than that of the vinyl acetate homopolymer and decreases in the order poly(3CPMI‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐VA) > poly(4‐CPMI‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐VA) > poly(2CPMI‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐VA).</jats:p>

Title: Graft copolymerization of acrylamide–methylacrylate comonomers onto cellulose using ceric ammonium nitrate
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The graft copolymerization of acrylamide–methylacrylate comonomers was carried out using ceric ammonium nitrate as initiator in the presence of nitric acid at 25 ± 1°C. The effects of feed molarity, feed composition, reaction time, and temperature on graft yield (%<jats:italic>G</jats:italic>) and other grafting parameters were investigated. The determination of rate of ceric (IV) ions disappearance as a function of feed molarity and reaction time was useful in the determination of the rate of ceric (IV) ions consumption during graft copolymerization. The graft yield (%<jats:italic>G</jats:italic>) in the presence of acrylamide increases because of the synergistic effect of acrylamide comonomer. The composition of the grafted chains (<jats:italic>F</jats:italic><jats:sub>AAm</jats:sub>) varies on varying the feed composition and reaction temperature but is almost constant during feed molarity variation. The Mayo and Lewis method was used to determine the reactivity ratios of acrylamide (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and methylacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), which are 0.65 and 1.07, respectively. The product of reactivity ratio (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>
<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) is less then unity; hence, an alternate arrangement of comonomer blocks in the grafted copolymer chain is proposed. The rate of graft copolymerization of comonomers onto cellulose is second power to the concentration of comonomers and square root to the concentration of ceric ammonium nitrate. Suitable reaction steps for graft copolymerization of comonomers onto cellulose are proposed. © 2002 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 86: 2631–2642, 2002</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic study by differential scanning calorimetry of the bulk copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethylmethacrylate with ethyleneglycoldimethacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article presents a kinetic study of the copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethylmethacrylate (HEMA) with ethyleneglycoldimethacrylate (EGDMA). First, the rate constant of decomposition, <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>d</jats:sub></jats:italic>, of azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) used to initiate the copolymerization was investigated. Then, the reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, of the monomers (HEMA and EGDMA), and the termination rate constant, <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>t</jats:sub></jats:italic>, were determined. Rate constants were obtained by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments. The decomposition rate constant of AIBN follows an Arrhenius law in the temperature range 320–400 K. Copolymerizations were carried out in the pans of the DSC apparatus at 353 K. The reactivity ratios, determined after analysis of the mixture composition by gas chromatography, exploitation of the data using the Meyer and Lowry equation, and a numerical method, were found equal to <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.811 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 6.548. Also from the reaction rate obtained by DSC, the dependence of the termination rate constant with conversion and temperature has been established. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 80: 1220–1228, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of ethylene with styrene catalyzed by a linked bis(phenolato) titanium catalyst
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of ethylene with styrene, catalyzed by 1,4‐dithiabutanediyl‐linked bis(phenolato) titanium complex and methylaluminoxane, produced exclusively ethylene–styrene copolymers with high activity. Copolymerization parameters were calculated to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>E</jats:sub> = 1.2 for ethylene and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0.031 for styrene, with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>E</jats:sub> <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0.037 indicating preference for alternating copolymerization. The copolymer microstructure can be varied by changing the ratio between the monomers in the copolymerization feed, affording copolymers with styrene content up to 68%. The copolymer microstructure was fully elucidated by <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectroscopy revealing, in the copolymers with styrene content higher than 50%, the presence of long styrene–styrene homosequences, occasionally interrupted by isolated ethylene units. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 44: 1908–1913, 2006</jats:p>

Title: Study on the aqueous two-phase copolymerization of cationic polyacrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Aqueous two-phase copolymerization of acrylamide (AM) and dimethylaminoethyl methacrylate methyl chloride (DMMC) was carried out in polyethylene glycol 20000 (PEG 20000) aqueous solution and with 2,2'-azobis(2- amidinopropane) dihydrochloride (V-50) as the initiator. The effects of the temperature, the PEG 20000 concentration, the <jats:italic>DMMC/AM molar ratio </jats:italic>and the V- 50 concentration on the initial monomer copolymerization rate (Rp), the total monomers conversion and the molecular weight of copolymers were systematically investigated. The initial copolymerization rate increased with an increase of temperature and V-50 content, contrary to the concentration of the PEG 20000 and DMMC. The molecular weight of the copolymers decreased with increasing the reaction parameters above mentioned. The apparent copolymerization activation energy of the system was calculated to be 65.7 kJ·mol<jats:sup>-1</jats:sup> according to Arrhenius equation. The optimal PEG 20000 content of the system was 15%~25% (based on the raw materials). The relationship between the initial copolymerization rate (Rp) and the initiator concentration was discussed, and the kinetics equation was Rp~ [I]<jats:sup>0.94</jats:sup>.</jats:p>

Title: Radiation‐induced copolymerization of methyl trifluoroacrylate with ethylene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methyl trifluoroacrylate (MTFA) with ethylene in bulk was induced by γ irradiation. The copolymerization was observed to proceed in the liquid monomer mixture of MTFA and ethylene at 25°C with the dose rates ranging from 5.0 × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup> to 1.0 × 10<jats:sup>6</jats:sup> rad/hr. A wide range of the initial monomer composition gives an almost equimolar and alternating copolymer. The highest polymerization rate was observed at the equimolar monomer composition. The dose rate exponent of the polymerization rate is unity. The reactivity ratios of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (MTFA) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (ethylene) were determined to be 0.034 and 0.14, respectively.</jats:p>

Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 7. Copolymerization of monomethyl itaconate with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of monomethyl intaconate (MMI) with styrene (St) initiated with 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile in solvents differing in dielectric constants and capability to form hydrogen bonds was investigated. The IR‐ and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopic studies of the monomer mixtures in four solvents have shown an influence of the solvent on the formation of hydrogen bonds and of other donor‐acceptor associates. The reactivity ratios of the monomer pairs in the different solvents are as follows: in chloroform, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMI</jats:sub> = 0,09 ± 0,05 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,14 ± 0,00; in acetonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMI</jats:sub> = 0,26 ± 0,10 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,36 ± 0,01; in dioxane, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMI</jats:sub> = 0,28 ± 0,01 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,55 ± 0,00; in acetone: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMI</jats:sub> = 0,18 ± 0,05 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,49 ± 0,00. The changes in the values of the reactivity ratios are connected with the ability of the solvents to govern the formation of hydrogen bonds among the MMI molecules and between the MMI and the solvent on the one hand and the formation of donor‐acceptor associates between both monomer molecules on the other. The increase of the concentration of associated monomer molecules which occur in chloroform leads to a decrease of the r‐values.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization Characteristics of Methyl Acrylate and Methyl Methacrylate. II. Analysis of Methyl Acrylate-Methyl Methacrylate Copolymers by Infrared Spectroscopy
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The infrared absorption spectra of polymers and copolymers of methyl acrylate and methyl methacrylate have been measured, and then used as the basis of a spectrophotometric method for the analysis of the copolymers. The 6.73 μ band, which may be due to methyl (–C–CH3) vibration, was selected as the key band for measuring the methyl methacrylate component, while the 6.89 μ band was used as the standard. The monomer reactivity ratios for copolymerization of methyl acrylate-methyl methacrylate system have been determined to be r1=0.5±0.1, and r2=2.3±0.4 (M1 methyl acrylate, M2; methyl methacrylate) at 130°C. These values are in good agreement with those previously obtained by the deuterium tracer method. It has also been shown that the procedure used in this study is appropriate for the analyses of methyl acrylate-methyl methacrylate copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of vinyl ketones with allylbenzene in the presence of zinc chloride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of 3‐buten‐2‐one (MVK) and 3‐methyl‐3‐buten‐2‐one (MIPK) with allylbenzene (AB) in the presence of zinc chloride (ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was studied. The apparent monomer reactivity ratio decreased with an increasing concentration of ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> added. By assuming a terpolymerization system as free vinyl ketone (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), vinyl ketone complexed with ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), and AB(M<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>), the absolute monomer reactivity ratios were determined by using the least squares method: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 0.0038, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> = 11.77, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 1.37, and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>23</jats:sub> = 3.77 for the MVK‐AB system, and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 0.0070, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> = 55.47, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 1.84, and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>23</jats:sub> = 11.16 for the MIPK‐AB system, respectively. It is seen from these values that the complexed vinyl ketones are more reactive to both polymer radicals which have free and complexed vinyl ketone units at its terminal position than the free vinyl ketones. <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for MVK and MIPK complexed with ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were found to be <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-24.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:03606376:media:POL170230801:tex2gif-inf-24" /> = 850, <jats:italic><jats:sup>e</jats:sup></jats:italic><jats:sub>(MVK)</jats:sub><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.97, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-30.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:03606376:media:POL170230801:tex2gif-inf-30" /> = 2.62, respectively.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and N‐phenylmaleimide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene (α‐MeSt) and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenylmaleimide (NPMI), the resulting copolymers were found to have a high alternating structure regardless of the ratio of comonomers in the feed. The monomer reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21 (NPMI) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03 (α‐MeSt) (Kelen–Tüdös method), the equilibrium constant of CT complex K was 0.02 L mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, and the energy of activation <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> was 73 kJ mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. From the equation <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>) + <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(CT) proposed by Shirota and coworkers, <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(f) and <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(CT) were calculated, and it was found that in toluene the copolymerization proceeds predominantly by the addition of free monomers. Copolymers prepared at an equimolar ratio of comonomers in the feed have a glass transition temperature <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> of 539 K (DSC method).</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Ethyl Vinyl Ketone with Styrene
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Acidic Aqueous-Phase Copolymerization of AA and HPEG Macromonomer: Influence of Monomer Concentration on Reactivity Ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Acidic Aqueous-Phase Copolymerization of AA and HPEG Macromonomer: Influence of Monomer Concentration on Reactivity Ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization with Ziegler‐Natta catalysts. Part I. Monomer reactivity ratios for two α‐olefin pairs
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Crystalline copolymers of styrene and 4‐methylpent‐1‐ene and styrene and 5‐methylhex‐1‐ene have been prepared with the catalytic system α‐TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>–AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> in toluene. The polymerizations were carried out in dilatometers with the use of a special stirring apparatus which is described. The copolymers produced were shown to be heterogeneous in composition. Fractions soluble in cold pentane are enriched in 5‐methylhex‐1‐ene and have x‐ray diffraction patterns similar to those of crystalline isotactic poly(5‐methylhex‐1‐ene). The fractions insoluble in cold pentane are enriched in styrene and on crystallization have x‐ray diffraction patterns similar to those of crystalline isotactic polystyrene. Infrared spectra were also examined. Determination of reactivity ratios gave the values: styrene (M)‐4‐methylpent‐1‐ene, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.89 ± 0.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 3.67 ± 0.22; styrene (M)‐5‐methylhex‐1‐ene, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.59 ± 0.057, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.00 ± 0.28. Statistical analysis shows that the copolymer is probably a mixture of block macromolecules, the chain backbones consisting mainly of one monomer type with short blocks of the other.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of a dendronized monomer with styrene and different acrylates: Determination of reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of a first‐generation dendronized monomer with styrene and different acrylates are determined. The obtained ratios as well as the copolymer compositions that can be expected are discussed in detail. The influence of the dendron on the polymerization potential of the monomer is estimated by comparing its reactivity to those of linear systems as well as using higher generations of the dendronized monomer. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem, 2013</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of vinyl cyclohexane and α‐methyl vinyl cyclohexane with acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of vinyl cyclohexane and α‐methyl vinyl cyclohexane with acrylonitrile in the presence of a complexing agent AlEtCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> results in the formation of alternate copolymers. In the copolymerization of vinyl cyclohexane with acrylonitrile the copolymer composition depends on the ratio of acrylonitrile to AlEtCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>. If this ratio is unity, alternating copolymers of the composition 1:1 are formed; with a ratio greater than unity statistical copolymers that contain more than 50% acrylonitrile units are produced. The <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy measurements indicate that the interaction between the comonomers and the complexing agent leads to the formation of ternary donor–acceptor complexes of equimolar composition. The equilibrium constants of these complexes at −60°C have been determined. The effects of temperature, nature of solvent and dilution on the yield, and composition of the copolymers of vinyl cyclohexane with acrylonitrile formed have been studied. By lowering the temperature the yield of copolymers increases but their composition remains equimolar. An increase in the polarity of the medium results in an increase in copolymer yield, whereas the yield decreases if the reaction is conducted in a donor‐solvent medium. Dilution of the reaction mixture disrupts the alternation of units in the macrochain of copolymers. The kinetic pecularities of copolymerization have been investigated. The linear dependence of the copolymerization rate on the product of comonomer concentration is observed. The rate of copolymerization is proportional to the square root of the incident light intensity. Various additions of radical type and irradiation accelerate the process of copolymerization. The mechanism of alternating copolymerization of vinyl cyclohexane monomers with acrylonitrile in the presence of AlEtCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> is discussed in terms of homopolymerization of the comonomer complex.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of alkyl acrylates with triallyl cyanurate: Kelen-Tüdös method applied for determining copolymerization reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization Parameters of 2-(N-Phthalimido) ethyl Methacrylate with Different Vinyl Monomers
Abstract: <jats:p>2-(N-phthalimido)ethyl methacrylate was prepared by the reaction of methacrylic acid with N-(2-hydroxyethyl)phthalimide in presence of N,N?-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide. The monomer reactivity ratios for copolymerization reactions of 2-(N-phthalimido)ethyl methacrylate with methyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, butyl acrylate and styrene, respectively, in solution with azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator, were estimated by nitrogen analysis. The structure of the copolymers was investigated by IR spectroscopy. The Q and e values for 2-(N-phthalimido)ethyl methacrylate were calculated. Some of the synthesized polymers were tested for their antimicrobial activity against bacteria and fungi.</jats:p>

Title: A new copolymerization equation
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A new copolymerization equation is suggested for the calculation of copolymer composition. The new equation is independent of reactivity ratios, so we can obtain the copolymer composition from experimental data when the reactivity ratios are unknown. The new equation has been verified by experimental data (styrene/methyl methacrylate, methyl methacrylate/vinyl chloride, and styrene/acrylonitrile systems). The results of the comparisons suggest that the new equation is satisfactory. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with maleamic acid derivatives and with carboxyphenylmaleimide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrylonitrile was copolymerized with two N‐arylmaleamic acids and with N‐3‐carboxyphenylmaleimide in dimethylformamide (DMF) using azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The reactivity ratios and the Q‐e parameters of these monomers were estimated, and the resulting copolymers were characterized by viscosity measurements and thermal analysis. Thermogravimetry and differential thermal analysis data showed an improvement in the thermal behaviour of the investigated copolymers compared with that of poly(acrylonitrile). Mechanisms illustrating the role of both the acidic group and the maleimide ring in the nitrile oligomerization were proposed. The produced copolymers showed an excellent affinity towards basic dyes and better color fastness towards UV light.</jats:p>

Title: Expansion of copolymerization theory (influence of neighboring units on radical reactivity with monomers)
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Equations are presented which allow for the first time a thorough definition of the detectable influence of <jats:italic>all</jats:italic> neighboring units on radical reactivity in copolymerization. These effects are expressed in terms of reactivity ratios involving the competition of two monomers for characteristic terminal chain sequences.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization parameters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization parameters, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>, have been calculated for several monomers whose relative reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic>, are available. The ratios and parameters are tabulated in an effort to bring the various data in the literature to a single source of reference.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization parameters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization parameters, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>, have been calculated for several monomers whose relative reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic>, are available. The ratios and parameters are tabulated in an effort to bring the various data in the literature to a single source of reference.</jats:p>

Title: Application of the Monte Carlo simulation method to the investigation of peculiar free‐radical copolymerization reactions: Systems with both reactivity ratios greater than unity (rA > 1 and rB > 1)
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>With a Monte Carlo simulationmethod, copolymer properties have been thoroughly studied, and the influence of the reactivity ratios and feed composition has been taken into consideration. Instantaneous alterations of the copolymer composition and copolymer heterogeneity, which is also called a randomness parameter, have been examined with data obtained from the simulation at each stage of the copolymerization reaction. The results prove the azeotropic behavior of copolymerization reactions in which both reactivity ratios are greater than unity, although some special reactivity ratio combinations ignore the azeotropic behavior. The copolymer composition reaches an azeotrope point at the end of the copolymerization reaction when the copolymerization is an azeotropic reaction. In addition, the randomness parameter takes its maximum value at the azeotrope point when reactivity ratio <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>A</jats:sub></jats:italic> is equal to reactivity ratio <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>B</jats:sub></jats:italic>. Finally, increasing the reactivity ratios causes no change in the trend of copolymer composition/feed composition curves when <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>A</jats:sub></jats:italic> is equal to <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>B</jats:sub></jats:italic>. However, the curves produced with larger <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>A</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>B</jats:sub></jats:italic> values show more fluctuations. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Tracer techniques for the determination of monomer reactivity ratios. IV. Monomer reactivity ratios for styrene–isoprene copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The ionization chamber‐vibrating reed electrometer assay technique has been improved in precision (±0.25% average deviation) and used to determine monomer reactivity ratios for the styrene—isoprene copolymerization. Values of <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> (styrene) = 0.50 (100°) and 0.54 (80°) and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.92 (100°, 80°) have been obtained for the radical initiated copolymerization. For γ‐irradiation initiation at 22°, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.66 and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.88. For butyllithium initiation, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.03 and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 5.9. The difference in the radical and γ‐radiation initiation values is considered in terms of possible partial ionic character of the radiation initiation process and possible temperature dependence of the reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic>) over the 22–100°C. range. The latter indicates a difference in activation energy of 0.8 kcal./mole for the radical to styrene and radical to isoprene propagation steps.</jats:p>

Title: Reactive polymers, 5. Synthesis of a 2,3‐epoxypropyl ethyl maleate/fumarate mixture and its copolymerization with styrene and ethylene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A mixture of 2,3‐epoxypropyl ethyl maleate and fumarate (<jats:bold>4</jats:bold>) was obtained from ethyl potassium maleate and 1‐chloro‐2,3‐epoxy propane.</jats:p><jats:p>Copolymerization of <jats:bold>4</jats:bold> with styrene was carried out and the monomer reactivity ratios were found to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,30 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,05 (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>: styrene, <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>: ester <jats:bold>4</jats:bold>). <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were found to be 0,55 and 1,28, respectively. Copolymerizations of <jats:bold>4</jats:bold> with ethylene were performed to improve the chemical reactivity of polyethylene, and the reactivity was studied by means of a homogeneous reaction with dibutylamine. The observed kinetic data may be divided into two parts: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>o</jats:sub> (non‐catalytic rate constant) = 1,75 · 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> dm<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> (product‐induced catalytic rate constant) = 2,25 · 10<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> dm<jats:sup>6</jats:sup> mol<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> in DMF at 70°C.</jats:p>

Title: Sodium-Catalyzed Copolymerization of 1,3-Butadiene and Styrene
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>1. A convenient laboratory procedure for the sodium-catalyzed copolymerization of butadiene and styrene has been described. Earlier attempts to accomplish this probably failed because the monomers were not sufficiently pure. 2. The copolymer of butadiene and styrene which results from sodium polymerization is different from the emulsion copolymer, GR-S, in several important respects. The sodium-catalyzed copolymer has a more nearly constant styrene content at different stages of conversion; it is made up of molecules with a relatively narrow molecular weight spread; it has a higher intrinsic viscosity; it is 100 per cent soluble in benzene (i.e., there is no gel) even at 100 per cent conversion; when treated with standard rubber antioxidant, it ages better; and it has a greater amount of the butadiene joined in the 1,2 manner (i.e., greater vinyl side-chain content). 3. The effects of such variables as temperature of polymerization, method of adding the monomer mixture to the catalyst, size of catalyst particles, and possible butadiene impurities on the polymerization have been studied. 4. The method has been extended to cover copolymerization of butadiene and m-methylstyrene to give a soluble copolymer of low molecular weight. Other styrene-type monomers gave less interesting copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene and methyl α‐cyanocinnamate, 1. Synthesis, NMR‐assignment, reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and methyl α‐cyanocinnamate was studied. The copolymers were investigated by means of NMR spectroscopy. From the assignment of the signals both in <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectra it follows that not only head‐to‐tail but also head‐to‐head coupling of styrene and methyl α‐cyanocinnamate monomeric units occurs in the copolymers. The composition data of the copolymers can be described by the penultimate model as seen from the linear distribution of the data points in a modified Kelen‐Tüdös representation.</jats:p>

Title: Vinyl Polymerization. 124. Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with Acrylamide
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: General relationships among monomers in copolymerization
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Although there is general recognition of the value of the Alfrey‐Price relationship, controversy has not abated concerning the theoretical basis for the equations and the accuracy of the monomer reactivity ratios predicted. A heretofore unrecognized possibility for approaching the problem of general monomer reactivity relationships appears to lie in the consideration of terpolymers. The relationship between monomer and terpolymer compositions is given by the equations
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
A more general and yet simplified relationship underlying terpolymers which has not been previously recognized is derived. This relationship is shown to hold for a wide range of monomer types and concentrations. The overall probability of initiating a, c, and b sequences immediately preceded by b, a, and c, respectively, and of undefined terminating units is equal to the probability of terminating a, c, and b sequences with b, a, and c units, respectively, but of undefined initiating units. This relationship of product probabilities is as follows:
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
and is shown to hold for numerous terpolymer and related copolymer systems. It follows that
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
Methods are presented for predicting the behavior of monomers A and C in copolymerization when the behaviors of A‐B and B‐C are known. Furthermore, it is shown that the value of eq. (3) is frequently in the range of 0.02–0.06. This result is probably related to the fact that terpolymerization of monomers of equal reactivity in equimolar concentrations will yield product probabilities equal to 0.037. Variations in individual probabilities require compensating changes in the other related probabilities. Application of this relationship allows the calculation of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>31</jats:sub> where <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>23</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>32</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> are known.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization and structure of copolymers of α, β‐unsaturated aldehydes with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical bulk copolymerization of styrene with acrolein, methacrolein, and α‐ethyl‐acrolein is studied and monomer reactivity ratios are determined. Employing the dilatometric method the overall rate of polymerization is measured and discussed with respect to the special structure of copolymers. Quantitative IR spectroscopy is used to elucidate the structure of copolymers, and the absorption behavior of copolymers is compared with the statistical theory on sequence length distribution.</jats:p>

Title: The homopolymerization and copolymerization of an azo dye, N‐methyl‐N‐[4‐(2,5‐dichlorophenyl) azophenyl]‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The properties of a polymerizable dye, N‐methyl‐N‐[4‐(2,5‐dichlorophenyl)azophenyl]‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>I</jats:bold>), its homopolymerization and the properties of the homopolymer were characterized. The copolymerization parameters (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> with styrene (St), methyl methacrylate (MMA), N,N‐dimethyl‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate, 2,2,2‐trichloroethyl methacrylate and methacrylic acid and the rates of copolymerization were determined in benzene solution at 50°C with 0.01 M 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The Alfrey‐Price e and Q constants were calculated for <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> using the r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values for the system <jats:bold>I</jats:bold>/St. The retardative effect of the azo group in the homopolymerization and copolymerization of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> was evaluated by determining the ratio of rate constants of addition of polymer radicals to the model azo compound and to the monomer in the homopolymerization of St and MMA. The relative permittivities of monomers and their solutions were measured, and the effect of the molecular interaction of comonomers on the composition of the copolymers was discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 2,2,2‐trifluoroethyl acrylate for dielectric materials: Structure and characterization
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization based on acrylonitrile (AN) and 2,2,2‐Trifluoroethyl acrylate (ATRIF) initited by AIBN was investigated in acetonitrile solution. The resulting poly(AN‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐ATRIF) copolymers were characterized by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H, <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C, and <jats:sup>19</jats:sup>F NMR and IR spectroscopy, and size exclusion chromatography (SEC). Their compositions were assessed by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR. The kinetics of radical copolymerization of AN with ATRIF was investigated from sereval experiments achieved at 70 °C from initial [AN]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[ATRIF]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> molar ratios ranging between 20/80 and 80/20 and was enabled to determine the reactivity ratios of both comonomers. From the monomer—polymer copolymerization curve, the Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdos laws enabled to assess the reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub>= <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.25 ± 0.04 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ATRIF</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.93 ± 0.05 at 70 °C) while the revised patterns scheme led to <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 1.03, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ATRIF</jats:sub> = 0.78 at 70 °C. In all cases, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> x <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ATRIF</jats:sub> product was close to unity, which indicates that poly(AN‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐ATRIF) copolymers exhibit a random structure. This was also confirmed by the Igarashi's and Pyun's laws which revealed the presence of AN‐ATRIF, AN‐AN, and ATRIF‐ATRIF dyads. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ATRIF were also assessed (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.62 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.93). The glass transition temperature values, <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>, of these copolymers increased from 17 to 61 °C as the molar percentage of ATRIF decreased from 77 to 16% in the copolymer. Thermogravimetry analysis of poly(AN‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐ATRIF) copolymers showed a good thermal stability compared to that of poly(ATRIF) homopolymer due to incorporation of AN comonomer. © 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem. <jats:bold>2013</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>51</jats:italic>, 3856–3866</jats:p>

Title: Anionic copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Previous work with anionic copolymerizations held that the terminal carbanion played no role in determining which monomer was next added. Recent work by Graham et al. has demonstrated that this is untrue for monomers of extremely dissimilar polarities. In this paper the kinetics of copolymerization of dissimilar monomers has been developed. As a result it is shown that the ratio of monomers in the initial copolymer <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] is directly proportional to the square of the initial monomer ratio ([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> when the monomers are dissimilar. The earlier theory resulted in a first‐power proportionality for all cases. Log—log plots of the equation <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] = <jats:italic>K</jats:italic>([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])<jats:italic><jats:sup>a</jats:sup></jats:italic> show that <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> has a value of 2.0 for styrene—methyl methacrylate, 1.0 for styrene—isoprene and 1.3 for methyl methacrylate—methacrylonitrile. The conclusion is drawn that values of <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> of 1.0 and 2.0 represent extremes of behavior for monomers of very similar and very dissimilar polarites. As a corollary of this it is concluded that reactivity ratios for these systems where <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> is not 1.0 are of questionable theoretical significance.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical solution copolymerization of the ionic liquid monomer 1‐vinyl‐3‐ethylimidazolium bromide with acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ionic liquid monomer 1‐vinyl‐3‐ethylimidazolium bromide (ViEtIM<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>Br<jats:sup>−</jats:sup>) was first used to copolymerize with acrylonitrile (AN) successfully under various conditions. This was achieved with azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator and dimethyl sulfoxide as the solvent. The kinetics of this copolymerization were studied.
